title: T-Bone (rapper)
text:
Rene Francisco Sotomayor, better known by the stage name T-Bone, is a <a href="Christian%20rap">Christian rap</a>per. His father is Nicaraguan and his mother is Salvadoran. His name came from being called 'Bones' as a youngster because he was very skinny. The 'T' was "added to give the name a little slang edge."
Music career.
According to published interview, he started rapping at the age of seven at parties and in "<a href="rap%20battles">rap battles</a>". He was close to getting a gangsta rap record, but, after changing his life, he opened for a noted rock group at that time which led him to getting signed to his first inspirational record deal that very night.
His first three albums: "Redeemed Hoodlum" in 1993, "Tha Life of a Hoodlum" in 1995 and "Tha Hoodlum's Testimony" in 1996 were released on the independent Metro One record label. All three albums were characterized by being <a href="gangsta%20rap">gangsta rap</a> albums, which was rare in the inspirational music scene at the time.
In 1997, he released "History of a Hoodlum", a compilation set of hits from his first three albums was released on the Metro One record label.
After a brief hiatus, T-Bone released his fourth album, and first on the <a href="Flicker%20Records">Flicker Records</a> music label, "<a href="Tha%20Last%20Street%20Preacha">Tha Last Street Preacha</a>", in 2001, to critical acclaim. "Tha Last Street Preacha" was nominated for the Rock Gospel Album <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a>. and saw T-Bone break into the <a href="contemporary%20Christian%20music">contemporary Christian music</a> market. It was the first rap album to debut at No. 7 on the Christian Contemporary Music charts.
2002 saw an increased exposure of T-Bone to both Christian and mainstream markets with the release of his fifth album, "Gospelalphamegafunkyboogiediscomusic". The album was characterized by the guest appearance of hip-hop legend "<a href="KRS-One">KRS-One</a>" on the title track – returning the favor of the controversial guest spot T-Bone had made on KRS-One's "<a href="Spiritual%20Minded">Spiritual Minded</a>" album earlier in the year.
2005 saw the release of his most controversial, and successful, album to date: "<a href="Bone-A-Fide">Bone-A-Fide</a>". "Bone-A-Fide"s album cover controversially featured T-Bone in an image evoking <a href="Che%20Guevara">Che Guevara</a>, leading to concerns that he was promoting <a href="communist">communist</a> ideologies – charges he denied. Adding to the controversy were collaborations with two major <a href="secular">secular</a> rappers: <a href="Mack%2010">Mack 10</a> and <a href="Chino%20XL">Chino XL</a>.
"Bone-A-Fide" was his first album not to be produced by long-time collaborator Chase Dante and, perhaps deliberately, saw T-Bone move away from the previous <a href="West%20Coast%20hip%20hop">West Coast</a> sound of his earlier albums to a smoother, more <a href="East%20Coast%20hip%20hop">East Coast</a> sound. Also, in 2005, he was featured as <a href="Jairus">Jairus</a> in the rock opera "<a href="%21Hero">!Hero</a>", along with <a href="Michael%20Tait">Michael Tait</a> of <a href="Tait%20%28band%29">Tait</a> and <a href="dc%20Talk">dc Talk</a>, <a href="Rebecca%20St.%20James">Rebecca St. James</a>, and <a href="Mark%20Stuart%20%28musician%29">Mark Stuart</a> of <a href="Audio%20Adrenaline">Audio Adrenaline</a>.
"<a href="Bone-Appetit%21">Bone-Appétit: Servin' Up tha Hits</a>", a compilation set of hits from his last three albums was released on September 25, 2007.
"Pa mi Dios y Pa mi Gente" ("For My God and For My People") was released on April 7, 2017 and "Broken English" was released on March 15, 2018.
Other works.
Film career.
T-Bone stars in the film "The Rally", co-starring <a href="Kenneth%20Copeland">Kenneth Copeland</a>. It was released in late 2009 to early 2010.
T-Bone's first major film role was in 2003, playing the role of Briggs, a rapping prisoner in the comedy-romance motion picture "<a href="The%20Fighting%20Temptations">The Fighting Temptations</a>", which starred <a href="Cuba%20Gooding%20Jr.">Cuba Gooding Jr.</a> and <a href="Beyonc%C3%A9%20Knowles">Beyoncé Knowles</a>. In the film, T-Bone performs the song "To da River" with secular artists <a href="Lil%20Zane">Lil Zane</a> and <a href="Montell%20Jordan">Montell Jordan</a>.
T-Bone also co-starred in the 2006 <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount</a>/<a href="MTV%20Films">MTV</a> film "<a href="All%20You%27ve%20Got">All You've Got</a>" which starred <a href="Ciara">Ciara</a> and <a href="Adrienne%20Bailon">Adrienne Bailon</a> of <a href="The%20Cheetah%20Girls%20%28group%29">The Cheetah Girls</a>.
His other films include <a href="Carman%20%28singer%29">Carman</a> and Stephen Yake's "R.I.O.T." and starred in "Black Rose" in 2003.
He appeared in the 2013 film "<a href="I%27m%20in%20Love%20with%20a%20Church%20Girl">I'm in Love with a Church Girl</a>".
